OVERVIEW: The Ceboya series consists of deep, very poorly drained, very slowly permeable soils that formed in fine-textured alluvial sediments of mixed origin. These soils are on broad, mountain valley flood plains and have slopes from 0 to 3 percent. Mean annual temperature is 42 to 46 degrees F., and mean annual precipitation is 16 to 20 inches.

TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine, mixed, superactive, frigid Typic Endoaquolls

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Ceboya silty clay loam, on the flood plain adjacent to the Mora River in an area under permanent throughout. (Colors are for moist soils unless otherwise stated.)
O--1 to 0 inches; dense sod of decomposing material and fibrous roots.
A11--0 to 9 inches; very dark gray (5Y 3/1) silty clay loam, dark gray (5Y 4/1) dry; weak medium subangular blocky structure; hard, friable, sticky and plastic; many fine, very fine and medium roots; common very fine tubular pores; few fine mica flakes; slightly effervescence; mildly alkaline; clear smooth boundary. (8 to 14 inches thick)
A12--9 to 14 inches; very dark grayish brown (2.5Y 3/2) heavy silty clay loam, dark grayish brown (2.5Y 4/2) dry; few fine distinct olive brown (2.5Y 4/4) mottles, light olive brown (2.5YR 5/4) dry; massive; very hard, firm, sticky and very plastic; many fine, very fine and medium roots; common very fine tubular pores; few fine mica flakes; slightly effervescence; mildly alkaline; clear wavy boundary. (0 to 6 inches thick)
C1g--14 to 23 inches; dark grayish brown (2.5Y 4/2) heavy silty clay loam, grayish brown (2.5Y 5/2) dry; many large prominent light olive brown (2.5Y 5/6) mottles, olive yellow (2.5Y 6/6) dry; massive; very hard, firm, sticky and very plastic; many fine, very fine and medium roots; few fine mica flakes; mildly alkaline clear wavy boundary. (8 to 12 inches thick)
C2g--23 to 41 inches; dark gray (N 4/) silty clay, gray (N 5/) dry; common medium prominent light olive brown (2.5Y 5/4) mottles, light yellowish brown (2.5Y 6/4) dry; massive; extremely hard, very firm, very sticky and very plastic; many fine, very fine and medium roots; few very fine tubular pores; few fine mica flakes; mildly alkaline; gradual wavy boundary. (10 to 20 inches thick)
C3g--41 to 60 inches; dark gray (N 4/) clay, gray (N 5/) dry; few fine distinct light olive brown (2.5Y 5/6) mottles, olive yellow (2.5Y 6/6) dry; massive; extremely hard, very firm, very sticky and very plastic; few fine roots; few very fine tubular pores; few fine mica flakes; 5 percent quartz pebbles; mildly alkaline.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Mora County, New Mexico; in the Village of Mora, about 400 feet south of NM highway 3 along fence line in NE1/4 sec. 14, T. 20 N., R. 15 E., in the Mora Land Grant.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  These soils have a fluctuating water table at depths of 0 to 3 feet.
The A horizon has neutral hue, 10YR, 2.5Y or 5Y, value of 3 through 5 dry, 2 or 3 moist, and chroma of 0 through 2. It commonly is silty clay loam, but the range includes clay loam, silt loam, and loam.
The C horizon has neutral hue, 10YR, 2.5Y or 5Y, value of 4 through 6 dry, 2 through 4 moist, and chroma 0 through 2. It is silty clay loam or clay loam in the upper part and silty clay or clay in the lower part. The lower part has 0 to 10 percent quartz pebbles. Some pedons have a B horizon, and most pedons have fine mica flakes.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Brycan and Saladon series in other families. Brycan soils have fine-loamy control sections. Saladon soils have cryic temperature regime.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Ceboya soils are on level to nearly level, broad mountain valley flood plains along major drainageways. The slope commonly is less than 1 percent, but the range is 0 to 3 percent. The soils formed in fine-textured alluvial sediments of mixed origin.  Elevations range from 7,200 to 8,500 feet. Mean annual temperature ranges from 42 to 46 degrees F., and mean annual precipitation ranges from 16 to 20 inches. The frost-free period ranges from 90 to 110 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Hesperus, Kinesava, Moreno, Holman, and the similar Brycan soils. These soils lack an aquic moisture regime.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Very poorly drained; runoff is very slow and ponded on most areas during high rainfall periods; very slow permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Most areas of the Ceboya soils are used for grazing livestock. Some areas have been developed for housing and small commercial buildings. Vegetation is mainly redtop, blue grama, saltgrass, and water-tolerant grasses and sedges.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  The Ceboya soils are not extensive. They occur in northern New Mexico.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content:
SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Mora County, New Mexico, 1981.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U. S. A.
